header.title: SECRETS MERVEILLEUX DE LA MAGIE NATURELLE ET CABALISTIQUE DU PETIT ALBERT, Traduits exactement sur l'original latin, intitulé: ALBERTI PARVI LUCII Libellus de mirabilibus naturæ arcanis. Enrichis de Figures mystérieuses; & la maniere de les faire. Nouvelle Édition, corrigée & augmentée.
header.category: Western Esotericism, Grimoire, Natural Magic, Cabalistic Magic

central_thesis: The book presents a comprehensive collection of rare and hidden natural and cabalistic secrets, asserting that through the precise application of astrological timing, sympathetic correspondences, and specific rituals, practitioners can leverage occult natural forces and elemental intelligences to achieve diverse practical outcomes in areas such as love, wealth, protection, health, and agriculture, without resorting to 'diablerie' but rather by understanding the inherent virtues of creation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Des secrets contenus dans ce petit trésor.
structure_content.summary: A detailed table of contents listing over 125 individual secrets and remedies, categorized by their intended purpose, ranging from love spells and wealth attraction to health cures and agricultural practices.

An introduction emphasizing the book's value as a 'universal treasure' of natural secrets, intended for all people. It claims these secrets operate within natural forces, are validated by experience, and derive from ancient philosophers and cabalists. The author advises on the importance of astrological timing for successful operations and clarifies that the magic is not 'diablerie' but a use of natural, albeit occult, virtues.

structure_content.chapter_title: De l'amour réciproque de l'homme & de la femme.
structure_content.summary: A section detailing various methods to induce love, fidelity, or mitigate desire. It includes recipes involving animal parts (hippomanes, dove liver, hare testicles), personal bodily fluids (blood), specific plants (Enula Campana), and the engraving of magical words (Scheva) on rings, all performed with specific timing (Fridays, before sunrise).

structure_content.chapter_title: Des Talismans de l'Antiquité, leur Origine et Usages d'iceux.
structure_content.summary: An extensive discussion on the origin and use of talismans, attributing their efficacy to planetary influences and the sympathetic connection between planets, metals, and engraved symbols. It provides detailed instructions and diagrams for constructing talismans for each of the seven classical planets (Sun, Moon, Mars, Mercury, Jupiter, Venus, Saturn), emphasizing the choice of metal, specific figures, numbers, and precise astrological timing.

structure_content.chapter_title: Modele des heures cabalistiques des sept planetes.
structure_content.summary: Tables illustrating the planetary hours for each day of the week, crucial for timing magical operations to align with favorable planetary influences. The author stresses the importance of working under the correct planetary hour for the intended magical effect.

structure_content.chapter_title: Maniere de faire la véritable eau céleste.
structure_content.summary: A complex alchemical recipe for 'Celestial Water' (Eau Céleste) involving numerous herbs, spices, minerals, and distillations. The subsequent section details its 'miraculous properties' as a universal medicine for various ailments, including plague, and its ability to prolong life and restore vigor.

Instructions for creating artificial mandrakes from bryonia root, consecrated through specific rituals involving animal products (three drowned bats in cow's milk) and dried in a special oven. These are claimed to bring good fortune, wealth, and success in games.

structure_content.chapter_title: Tromperie de la mandragore artificielle. / Autre tromperie par la tête de S. Jean.
structure_content.summary: Exposés of fraudulent magical practices, such as a 'mandragore' animated by a lodestone in a ring to appear to give oracles, or a 'Head of St. John' using a voice tube, demonstrating the author's attempt to distinguish genuine occult practices from charlatanism.

structure_content.chapter_title: La main de gloire dont se servent les scélérats voleurs...
structure_content.summary: A description of the infamous Hand of Glory, allegedly used by thieves to paralyze victims. The text details its preparation from the hand of a hanged man, treated with specific salts, dried, and used as a candle holder. It also provides counter-charms, such as an ointment for door sills made from black cat bile and owl blood.

structure_content.chapter_title: Pour se rendre invisible par le moyen d'un anneau.
structure_content.summary: Instructions for an invisibility ring, to be made of fixed mercury, set with a stone from a huppe's nest, and engraved with a specific inscription. It is to be consecrated with Mercury perfumes and carried in the huppe's nest for nine days. A counter-charm using a lead ring with a weasel's eye is also provided.

key_concepts.definition: Objects, typically metals, engraved with specific planetary symbols, numbers, and figures, created under auspicious astrological conditions (planetary hours and aspects) to channel beneficial planetary influences for various purposes, such as wealth, love, or protection.

Specific divisions of the day and night, each ruled by one of the seven classical planets. Performing magical operations during the hour corresponding to the desired planetary influence is considered crucial for success.

A form of magic based on the principle of 'like affects like' or that things once connected continue to influence each other. It involves using substances or objects that correspond to the desired outcome, such as animal parts, plants, or personal effects, to create a magical link.

Elemental spirits of the earth, described as reasonable creatures who can be influenced by humans. They are associated with guarding hidden treasures and can be swayed through specific planetary perfumes and respectful conduct.

A complex alchemical preparation, distilled from a variety of herbs, minerals, and wine, believed to possess miraculous healing, rejuvenating, and life-prolonging properties, functioning as a universal medicine.

A notorious magical implement, described as the mummified hand of a hanged criminal, used by thieves as a candle holder to induce paralysis or deep sleep in occupants of a house. The text also includes methods for counteracting its effects.

An alchemical substance, a highly purified and stable form of mercury, which serves as a base material for certain talismans and alchemical transmutations. Its preparation is detailed as a lengthy and precise process.
A cabalistic word or name, often to be written in blood or engraved, used in various charms, particularly for love, to imbue objects with magical efficacy.
A piece of flesh found on the forehead of a newborn foal, believed to possess potent virtues for inducing love when dried and administered or touched to the desired person.

practical_system.description: The 'Petit Albert' outlines a comprehensive system of natural and cabalistic magic, heavily reliant on astrological timing (planetary days and hours), sympathetic correspondences (animal parts, plants, minerals), and specific ritual actions including prayers, incantations, and alchemical preparations. It aims to manipulate natural forces and elemental intelligences for a wide range of practical purposes, from personal gain and protection to healing and agricultural improvements. The system distinguishes itself from 'diablerie' by emphasizing natural virtues and ancient wisdom, positioning itself as a practical manual for harnessing hidden natural powers.
tools: Metals: Gold (Sun), Silver (Moon), Fixed Mercury (Mercury), Iron (Mars), Tin (Jupiter), Copper/Brass (Venus), Lead (Saturn).
Minerals & Salts: Vitriol, saltpeter, alum, borax, agate, jet (jais), ambergris, crystal mineral, chalk, quicklime, lodestone (aiman), opiment.

Plants & Herbs: Marjoram, thyme, laurel, myrtle, juniper, lemon peel, orange peel, iris, storax, benjoin, camphor, euphorbium, bdellium, hellebore, ash, poppy, henbane, mandrake, bryony, vervain, plantain, rue, elder, sage, arnica, mugwort, betony, saffron, ginger, cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg, citron, various flowers and seeds.

Animal Products: Hippomanes, wolf genitals/eyes, hare testicles/belly, dove liver, hen heart, serpent skin/tongue, craps parts, crow blood, bat brain, weasel eye, huppe blood/nest stone, chameleon liver, caille heart, black cat blood/bile, owl blood, human fat, animal grease (boar, wolf, crocodile, pig), human semen, animal bone ash, honey.
Alchemical & Lab Equipment: Alembics, crucibles, furnaces, stills, retorts, mortars, presses, filtering cloths (linen, silk), glass phials, new earthen pots, wooden spatulas.

Ritual Paraphernalia: Rings, staffs, candles (especially human fat candles, blessed candles), specific types of paper, ink (own blood), specific containers for offerings/preparations, mirrors, compasses, small statues/dolls.

Inscriptions & Words: Magical words like 'Scheva,' 'JA SA-BAOTH,' 'HVTY,' 'Adam,' and specific orations and incantations ('Kyrios clementissime,' 'OMOUSIN ALBOMATATOS,' 'Jesus passant,' 'Apparuit Dominus Simoni,' 'Berit fera').
Timing Instruments: Sundials, astronomical tables for Sun/Moon rise, planetary hour tables (explicitly provided for each day of the week).
rituals: Astrological Talisman Construction: Engraving planetary figures, numbers, and names on specific metals (e.g., gold for Sun, silver for Moon, fixed mercury for Mercury) during auspicious planetary hours and celestial conjunctions. Perfumes corresponding to each planet are used for consecration.

Sympathetic Charms: Utilizing animal parts (e.g., hippomanes for love, wolf genitals for fidelity, huppe blood for divination) and plant extracts (e.g., Enula Campana for love) based on inherent 'virtues' or a 'sympathy' with the desired outcome, often performed at specific times (e.g., Fridays before sunrise).

Alchemical Preparations: Detailed recipes for substances like 'Eau Céleste' (Celestial Water), 'Baume de Mercure' (Mercury Balm), and fixed Mercury, involving complex distillations, calcinations, and infusions of herbs, minerals, and animal products for universal remedies or alchemical transmutations.

Elemental Engagement (Gnomes): Using specific 'perfumes' (incenses compounded from planetary-correspondent ingredients) and invocations (e.g., the 'Oraison de Salamandres') to attract and gain assistance from earth elementals, primarily for treasure discovery and protection in mines.

Counter-Magical Practices: Instructions for disarming malevolent magical artifacts, such as the Hand of Glory or invisibility rings, using specific counter-charms, materials (e.g., weasel eye, hyena hair), and precise timing.

Healing & Protection Spells: Employing combinations of herbs, minerals, and specific prayers or incantations (e.g., the 'Jesus-Christ' formula for wound healing) for a variety of physical ailments, protection against diseases like plague, or inducing specific states such as insensitivity to torture or fire immunity.

Agricultural and Animal Management Spells: Methods to protect crops from pests (crapaud and bat), increase harvest yields, ensure fishing abundance, multiply pigeons, and manage horses (sweetening a furious horse, increasing stamina).

relevant_quotes.text: LE véritable curieux, qui desire de profiter dans les secrets les plus rares & les plus cachés de la nature, doit, avec épanchement de cœur, ouvrir les yeux de son entendement sur ce que je lui ai ramaffé avec beaucoup de soin & d'exactitude dans ce petit volume.

Que l'on n'attribue point à magie ou diablerie, si dans quelques-uns des merveilleux secrets que je donnerai, on se sert de certains paroles ou figures; car elles ont leur vertu & efficacité [9] indépendamment de la magie, & les anciens sages hébreux s'en sont servis avec beaucoup de religion.

Personne ne peut, sans témérité, révoquer en doute que les astres & planetes célestes n'aient des influences dominantes sur tout ce qui est dans ce bas univers; car puisque l'on voit & que l'on éprouve sensiblement que les planetes dominent, par leurs influences sur l'homme, qui est l'image de Dieu & avantagé de la raison; à combien plus forte raison doit-on croire qu'elles dominent & influent sur les métaux, sur les pierres, & sur [61] tout ce que la nature & l'art peuvent produire; puisque toutes ces choses sont moindres que l'homme, & plus propres à recevoir, sans résistance, leurs influences étant privées de la raison & libre arbitre...

Mais ce qui est digne d'être su & bien remarqué, cx'est que les sept planetes n'influent jamais plus efficacement que par l'entremise des sept métaux qui leur sont propres, c'est-à-dire, qui ont de la sympathie avec leur substance...

La disposition cabalistique de ces genres planétiques n'est pas une des [145] moins curieuses productions des sages sectateurs de la science occulte des astres: on y voit que les figures des planetes se trouvent chacune à la premiere heure de son jour, sans anticiper l'une sur l'autre, ni interrompre leur ordre dans tout le cours des heures des jours de la semaine, & l'on a observé que c'est ordinairement à ces heures que les planetes ont de favorables aspects...

critical_analysis.relevance: The 'Petit Albert' is a seminal work in the grimoire tradition, particularly influential in French and European popular magic from the 18th century onwards. It synthesizes elements of traditional natural magic, Cabalistic principles, and rudimentary alchemy with folk remedies and superstitions. Its enduring relevance lies in its practical approach to addressing common human needs and anxieties, reflecting a worldview where occult forces were actively harnessed. It bridges scholarly Hermeticism with accessible, recipe-based magic, making it a crucial text for understanding the dissemination and popularization of esoteric ideas.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The book explicitly targets 'le véritable curieux' (the true seeker) and claims utility for a broad spectrum of society, from 'noble comme le roturier' (nobles as well as commoners), 'négociant de ville comme le laboureur de la campagne' (city merchants as well as country farmers), and even 'le bon conducteur de sa famille' (the good head of a family). This indicates a deliberate attempt to appeal to a wide audience, encompassing both those with academic interest in occult philosophy and ordinary people seeking practical magical solutions for everyday problems.
